reviewText:
The video review is here: http://youtu.be/JxQg4_qM-I8

After beating the first act, here are some thoughts about the game:
The artstyle is farily distinct and not that common at all.
The soundtrack and sounddesign is really nicely done.
The levels are designed pretty well, though they are quite linear.
The first bossfight was, as expceted, a big mashup of previous mechanics, which is not necessarily bad.
The game works fine with the keyboard, however playing it on a TV with a controller is even more recommended, especially for local coop.
Performancewise I found nothing to complain about.
So overall, I have to say the game is certainly worth the asking price, even moreso when you are interested in playing an interesting, challening puzzleplatformer.

Edit: as of 23. of April, the game does not feature online coop on its storepage anymore, which it did prior to release. Hopefully the devs will have a online coop implemented relatively soon.

reviewText:
Fantasticly made co-op puzzle-platformer that really makes you think and coordinate with your team-mate.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=623463807

I've played throught the first world so far with a friend and attempted some speedruns and perfect levels and we both had a lot of fun doing so.

You only have to think about moving and jumping but when you consider you are controlling two characters combined with coordinating with your partners two characters this can create a nice amount of depth to the game.  It creates moves like quadruple jump" and also situations where you have to stack your characters in particular color order to navigate passed obstacles!

This is a great example of how a co-op game should be!"

reviewText:
I'm the kind of guy who really likes co-op platformers.  So I'd been chomping at the bit since I heard about the game last December.  And Kalimba did not disappoint!  Some notes:

* stacking is harder than it looks... you need a ledge or a hole or something to do it
* more platform-y than puzzle-y
* difficult, but not extremely so (as some reviews implied)
* did not cause any existential marriage crises (as some reviews warned)
* got very exciting at some points
* similar feel to ibb&obb, but we liked Kalimba much better
* visual style is very nice
* lots of jokes that are ... somewhat funny

The scoring system is up to 70 points for getting all the goodies, minus 1 for each death.  The goodies are kept even when you die.  So you can get a pretty good score without being amazing, but it's quite hard to get all 70 points (and a golden totem).

The game is VERY short.  We completed all 20 co-op levels (so including dark void DLC) in 3 hours.  We didn't get 70 points in all the levels, and I'd say there's about a 50-50 chance that we care enough to go back.  Many of the levels introduced interesting gamplay mechanics, but by the end thing started to feel same-y.

So if you want to play a co-op puzzle platformer and you and your partner are both decent at platformers, then get this game!

reviewText: Kalimba is a great game that is really clever and provides the player with a nice mix of both action and puzzles. The sound, art and gameplay are all fantastic and really sets this game apart from other puzzle-platformers. The co-op is is a mix of coordination, frustration and fun which will test even the best of friendships. All in all well worth the $ albeit a bit short.

reviewText: Kalimba is a must-play for anyone who grew up playing games like Super Mario World and Kirby. This spiritual game effectively captures the spirit of the difficult traversing of a platformer mixed with a brilliant swapping puzzle mechanic that works without fail.\n\nRead the full review at GeeksUnderGrace.com

reviewText: I came into the game loving it. The meta hoebear was kinda funny and cool, the story was intruiging enough, and the graphics looked nice. The first few levels took some brain tugging, but nothing overly complex. When the game introduced changeable gravity the game went from recommend to not. If you are using the keyboard you are forced to use left control as the gravity switcher. It might seem fine, but when you have to make twitchy moves it becomes impossible because you cannot use the right arrow and control at the same time. If the devs added in changeable controls I would return to the game. For now I'll let it sit in the library.

reviewText: Let me first acknowledge that I didn't do enough research on the game; it's MY fault that I bought the game thinking there was online co-op when there isn't.  I enjoy the game, the little bit that I've played I think the mechanics are fun, and the gameplay is challenging.\n\nThat said, I think that it's simply inconceivable in the year 2015 to not have online co-op as an option.  I've heard people say, it's just not possible to play this over the internet
date: the amount of communication the players need to have simply makes it impossible to play online."  I think that's just a crock of bologna
helpfulPercent: Vent and any number of other VOIP services mean that you can have just as much communication over the web as you can with somebody sitting in the same room.\n\nI think this game definitely has that nostalgic feel to it
votesTotal: like an evolved Mario or Kirby but I just can't believe it doesn't have online co-op."

reviewText: This is a pretty simple action-platformer with a bunch of neat puzzles built into its unique movement mechanic. I didn't try improving my scores, but the ranking system that puts deaths and collectibles in a tug of war is really smart. Great art and audio. Hoe Bear as a story teller is a little out of place, but I still enjoy the silliness in the writing.\n\nOverall it's a great game that ends before it outstays its welcome. The DLC adds some cool mechanics and is a little harder, but it made me sad to see what becomes of the characters that I enjoyed pre-DLC.

Excellent couch co-op. My wife and I had a blast playing this last night. it also has a single player component. We loved the art design, level design, team work, and comedic cut scenes. worth every penny.

Satisfying puzzles, tight controls, and great art. Everything feels very polished and well-thought-out. The puzzles are difficult, but not ridiculously so; when you fail, it feels like it's your fault. Great game!

I really enjoyed it. I was looking for games to play similar to Super Meat Boy and someone gave me this game, didn't take long to beat but for the time I played it, I had a lot of fun.

Awesome little coop game. Play this with a friend and some controllers and this game will really test your friendship.

The good:
- Interesting ideas, which work and feel polished
- Pleasing visual and musical styles
- Challenging, yet not frustrating
- Separate co-op campaign for two players

The bad:
- ...the co-op campaign SHORT: 10 levels and beaten in an hour
- There's only a single mechanic in the co-op campaign
- co-op and singleplayer dlc sold separately for a relatively expensive price - should be included from the get-go

I would not recommend it for the co-op campaign only, but as a whole it is a good package. I bought the game + DLC combo package on sale (~7,5â‚¬ total price), and for that price it is a good buy.
Stop reading this and go play Kalimba.
